Tried both feisty and the current release... no dice on either one.
what stage do you get to when you boot?

I've gotten to two different stages -- when I plug in my old IDE DVD drive, it will get to the point where I'm supposed to partition disks (that it can't see because they're running on that chipset), and if I'm using the SATA drive, I get to the part where it can't detect my DVD RAM drive.
perhaps you can install to a PATA hard disk and compile a kernel with whatever possibly experimental driver you need for the SATA disks.
I'd do that, but I really don't want any PATA drives in my system..
not even for as long as it takes to get it going?
When I get the SATA drive up, won't the install still be on the PATA drive?  I'm lost on that...
yes, but you can transfer it and adapt /etc/fstab
Hm... sounds like that could cause lots of breakage...
it could, but won't if you do it right.

compile a kernel .deb with the driver you need. Partition the SATA drive from the PATA installation. Copy the PATA partition contents to the SATA target with a live CD. Chroot the target system and install the kernel .deb and grub. Bob's your uncle.
